awd_titl_txt: QLCI-CG: Nevada Institute for Quantum Sciences and Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
The Quantum Leap Challenge Institutes (QLCI) program is part of the Quantum Leap, one of the research Big Ideas promoted by the National Science Foundation. This award is a QLCI Conceptualization Grant, which supports activities to build capacity among teams planning for the large-scale, interdisciplinary Challenge Institute projects that aim to advance the frontiers of quantum information science and engineering. Research at these Institutes will span the focus areas of quantum computation, quantum communication, quantum simulation, and/or quantum sensing. The Institutes are expected to foster multidisciplinary approaches to specific scientific, technological, and workforce development goals in these fields.
 
This Conceptualization Grant will develop well-formulated plans for a future Challenge Institute proposal along the themes of quantum sensing and quantum computation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of the QLCI Conceptualization Grant are to:

  • identify and consolidate current expertise in Nevada
  •  explore ideas for cross-disciplinary collaboration
  •  develop and nurture industry and government partners
  • identify and develop research goals for the QLCI 
  • develop plans for student recruitment for the QLCI 
  • develop plans for outreach activities for the QLCI
  •  investigate other QLCI teams to collaborate with 

Because of the continued COVID restrictions, many of the proposed outreach activities have been curtailed and re-configured toward a remote access platform. In 2019-2020, we held two workshops, one in person, Nov 2019 at UNLV, in which researchers from UNLV, UNR, and LANL participated. Another virtual workshop was held at UNR in the Spring of 2020. These workshops identified and consolidated goals for a Nevada Institute for Quantum Science and Technology (NIQST). We initiated outreach activities with the Clark county school system. Four new junior faculty, two at UNLV and two at UNR, were incorporated into the QLCI-NIQST mission. Several quantum-centered proposals were submitted by NIQST faculty. Yan Zhou (UNLV) was awarded a major instrumentation grant securing a frequency comb facility at UNLV. Nevada QLCI-Co-PI A. Salamat (UNLV) was a co-author of the landmark advance in room-temperature superconductivity published in 2020. The NSF cited this advance as a " Breakthrough in the long sought-for quest for the holy grail of energy efficiency." This scientific milestone will propel the Salamat Lab at UNLV to become a leading player in studying and applying quantum-enabled phenomena at extreme conditions. Several QLCI faculty attended virtual quntum centered workshops and conferences in the 2020-21 funding period.In the funding year 2021-2022, we invited several prominent researches in the Quantum Information Sciences (QIS) to present at our NIQST Colloquium series.

They Include

Dr.  Yu Liu,  National Institute of Standards and Technology, Boulder, CO.  Title: Probing and controlling reactions at sub-microkelvin temperatures. Date: Nov 19 2021.

Prof.  Hartmunt Hafner, Dept. of Physics, UC Berkeley. Title: Coherent control of rotating ion strings: toward observing quantum statistics in a new regime. Date: April 8 2022.

Prof. Chris Hoofnagle, Berkeley Center for Law & Technology, UC. Berkeley. Title: Law and Policy for the Quantum Age. Date April 15 2022.

Prof. Roman Krems., University of British Columbia, Vancouver CA. Title: Can quantum computers be used to improve classical Bayesian machine learning models? April 30 2022.

QLCI funds where used to support travel to and participation in the Gordon Research Conference 2022 Molecular Interactions, held at Stoneham College in Massachusetts; Dates July 10-15 2022. Participants included Naduvalath Balakrishnan (Nevada QLCI-CoPI) and Yan Zhou (Nevada QLCI senior Investigator). QLCI funds where also used to support registration fee for the 2022  ACS Western Regional Meeting, to be held on Oct 21, 2022 at the Flamingo Hotel in Las Vegas Nevada. Participants included

  1. Prof. Timur Tscherbul, UNR.
  2. Prof. Yan Zhou, UNLV.
  3. Dr. Nandini Mukerjee, Stanford.
  4. Dr. Dongzheng Yang, UNM.
  5. Prof. Jun Ye, JILA (UC Colorado, Boulder).
  6. Prof. Heather Lewandowsky, JILA  (UC Colorado, Boulder).
  7. Dr. Yu Liu,  NIST
  8. Dr. Brian Kendrick, LANL.
  9. Dr. Humberto da Silva Jr., UNLV.
  10. Prof. Eric Hudson, UCLA.
  11. Prof. Naduvalath Balakrishnan, UNLV.
  12. Prof. Bernard Zygelman, UNLV.
